metadata.title: Thermodynamic analysis and optimization of an integrated Rankine power cycle and nano-fluid based parabolic trough solar collector

Article history: Received 25 February 2016 Received in revised form 8 May 2016 Accepted 9 May 2016 Available online 14 May 2016
Keywords: Parabolic trough solar collector Exergy efficiency Nano-fluid Optimization Thermal storage
a b s t r a c t
In this paper, the performance of an integrated Rankine power cycle with parabolic trough solar system and a thermal storage system is simulated based on four different nano-fluids in the solar collector system, namely CuO, SiO2, TiO2 and Al2O3. The effects of solar intensity, dead state temperature, and volume fraction of different nano-particles on the performance of the integrated cycle are studied using second law of thermodynamics. Also, the genetic algorithm is applied to optimize the net output power of the solar Rankine cycle. The solar thermal energy is stored in a two-tank system to improve the overall performance of the system when sunlight is not available. The concept of Finite Time Thermodynamics is applied for analyzing the performance of the solar collector and thermal energy storage system. This study reveals that by increasing the volume fraction of nano-particles, the exergy efficiency of the system increases. At higher dead state temperatures, the overall exergy efficiency is increased, and higher solar irradiation leads to considerable increase of the output power of the system. It is shown that among the selected nano-fluids, CuO/oil has the best performance from exergy perspective.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
During the past decade, serious issues related to fossil fuels including limited energy resources in the world, environmental pollutions, and global warming have made the renewable energies to be utilized as alternative resources. Solar energy, as one of the most promising renewable resources of energy, can be converted to thermal energy using trough collector system and solar concentrators, and then to electrical energy using a steam turbine [1,2]. Power generation systems based on parabolic solar collectors is well established and commercialized all over the world in the past two decades [3].
Parabolic trough collector is considered as a suitable device to derive power generation systems with operating temperatures up to 400 C [4]. The main challenge in the operation of the parabolic collectors is how to minimize thermal losses during absorption and transfer of heat. Exergy analysis can be utilized as a useful method to evaluate the irreversibility associated with a solar system to determine the optimum operating conditions of the solar collector [5].
Extensive investigations have been done on solar thermal systems. Singh et al. carried out an exergy analysis on 35-megawatt
parabolic trough power plant in India. The results of their study indicate that the most exergy loss of the system is related to high temperature heat exchanger and exergy losses in the low temperature heat exchanger is very low [6]. They proposed several methods to reduce exergy losses and to increase the efficiency of the system. Bakos et al. evaluated the efficiency of solar trough collector as a function of input heat flux, intensity of solar radiation and the aperture size of the parabolic collector. It is shown that the efficiency is improved by increasing the input heat flux and reducing the absorber pipe diameter [7].
Al-Sulaiman et al. applied exergy analysis to evaluate the performance of parabolic trough solar collectors integrated with a combined steam and organic Rankine cycle. The results show that the R-134a and R600a combined cycles have the highest and lowest exergy efficiencies, respectively, among the considered cases [8]. Reddy et al. reported an exergy analysis on the components of the solar thermal power plant system, including parabolic trough collector/receiver and Rankine heat engine. Also, they optimized the operating pressure of a Rankine heat engine in order to achieve the maximum efficiency. The results show that the energy and exergy efficiencies of thermal power plant increased by 1.49% and 1.51% with increasing pressure from 90 to 105 bar, respectively [9]. An exergy and energy analysis on a solar thermal power system is reported by Singh et al. [10]. The energy analysis indicates that the condenser of the heat engine has the maximum

Baghernejad and Yaghoubi performed exergy analysis to evaluate and optimize performance of integrated solar combined cycle. The result indicate that the major sources of exergy destruction are as follow: the combustor, collector, heat exchangers and pump/turbines [11].
A novel method to increase the efficiency of the solar collector system is to utilize nano-particles as a heat transfer medium since they have better thermal properties as compared to the base fluid. Yousefi et al. studied the effect of using Al2O3–H2O nano-fluid as an absorbing medium in a flat-plate solar water heater [12]. The results indicate that by using 0.2 wt% of Al2O3 nano-fluid the efficiency of solar collector enhances by 28.3% in comparison with water as working fluid. In another study, Liu et al. investigated the influence of water-based CuO nano-fluids in an evacuated tubular solar air collector integrated with simplified compound parabolic concentrator and open thermosyphon. The results indicate that if using nano-fluid as the working fluid of open thermosyphon, the air outlet temperature and collecting efficiency of
the solar air collector will have significant improvement [13]. Faizal et al. demonstrate that nano-fluids have high energy and exergy efficiencies comparing with base fluids. The efficiency of solar collector increased up to 23.5% using SiO2 nano-fluid [14]. A research by Faizal et al. indicates that nanoparticles with higher density and lower specific heat have higher thermal efficiency, and CuO based nano-fluid leads to the highest efficiency in comparison with other nano-fluids including SiO2, TiO2 and Al2O3 [1].
The main objective of this study is to conduct an energy and exergy analysis on parabolic trough solar system integrated with a Rankine cycle, and to evaluate the overall system performance based on four different nano-fluids as working fluid in trough collector system, namely CuO, SiO2, TiO2 and Al2O3. The performance of a two-tank thermal energy storage system integrated with a solar concentrating collector is evaluated based on Finite Time Thermodynamics (FTT). The effects of solar intensity, dead state temperature, and volume fraction of different nano-particles on exergy and energy efficiency are studied. Also, the genetic algorithm is applied to optimize the net power output and exergy efficiency of the integrated cycle.

sections.heading: 2. System description
sections.text:
A solar thermal power plant is considered that consists of solar collector system, thermal energy storage system (TES) and steam Rankine cycle. Fig. 1 shows a flow diagram of two-tank TES system that is integrated into a parabolic trough collector and Rankine cycle. The solar collector subsystem is a series of parabolic concentrators, in which the inner lining of reflectors concentrates solar energy on an absorber tube that is installed along the focal length. Heat is transferred to the heat transfer fluid (HTF) that is circulating inside the central tube of solar collectors. A portion of the high energy HTF from the collector flows through a heat exchanger where superheated steam is generated, and it drives the Rankine cycle and produces electric power by rotating the shaft connected to an electric generator [3].
Another portion of the hot HTF existing the collector is utilized to heat up a mineral oil as the thermal storage medium. The thermal energy storage unit is charged during sunny hours using the hot HTF through the heat exchanger where its temperature elevates about 573 K. The heated oil is stored in a hot storage tank. During discharge mode, i.e. when solar energy is not available, the TES operates in reverse direction and provides the required thermal energy for producing steam and generating electric power.
A mathematical model is developed for analyzing the performance of the parabolic trough collector integrated with the Rankine cycle and thermal storage system. The Engineering Equation Solver (EES) software is used for thermodynamic analysis of the integrated system. The main input data used in the mathematical model are listed in Table.1. A high-speed, multi-valve steam turbine is utilized. This type of steam turbine has both advantages of an impulse style turbine and a reaction style turbine that ensures energy efficiency of higher than 80%.
The thermodynamic analysis consists of energy and exergy balances for each component based on the following assumptions:
Potential and kinetic energy changes are negligible. The system operates under transient condition. The thermodynamic analysis of solar system including energy storage is based on finite-time approach. Chemical exergy of working fluids is not considered.

sections.heading: 3.4. Exergy analysis
sections.text:
Exergy analysis is an illuminating technique based on the Second Law of Thermodynamics (SLT) for rational and meaningful evaluation and comparison of processes and systems. The SLT is used to find the optimum performance conditions of a system. This approach is based on investigation of the causes of system irreversibility in order to identify the operating conditions that lead to minimum exergy destruction rate. The exergy is defined as the maximum achievable work from a system or process when it reaches to an equilibrium with a reference environment. In fact, exergy is the quality of energy. The exergy transfer due to shaft work is equal to the shaft work. However, the exergy transfer due to heat transfer depends on the temperature at which it occurs in relation to the dead state temperature, i.e. environment temperature. Exergy efficiency is considered as precise criteria for evaluating the performance of a system, because different types of energy are directly considered in terms of exergy.
Exergy analysis of the solar trough collector system provides access to optimal design and elucidates the opportunities for reducing exergy destruction. Minimization of exergy destruction in thermo-fluid systems can be accomplished by approaching the maximum exergy efficiency. Using the exergy balance on each section of the solar system, exergy efficiency can be calculated and the irreversibility of each section is determined. sections.heading: 4. Optimization
sections.text:
Genetic Algorithm (GA) as one of the evolutionary algorithms is used to determine the optimal working conditions. GA generates a very large collection of possible solutions to solve a problem, then each of these solutions is evaluated using a ‘‘fitness function”. This algorithm is quite effective if the correct parameters are selected [28,11].
A mathematical model for optimization consists of three main parts including objective functions, decision variables and the problem constraints. These are explained here as applied in the optimization algorithm. The objective function for this study is the net generated power by the solar Rankine cycle and the overall exergy efficiency. sections.heading: 5. Validation of results
sections.text:
The solar collector thermodynamic model that is developed in this study is validated using the results presented by Singh et al. [10]. As shown in Table 4, the total energy absorbed by the solar collector (Qs) and the useful heat gain by the collector (Qu) are compared with those in the reference study [10].
The overall exergy efficiency of the integrated system at different dead state temperatures is compared with a study by Abid et al. [29] for Al2O3 nano-fluid. As shown in Table 4, at higher dead state temperatures, the exergy efficiency is slightly increased.
Also, the performance of solar collector is qualitatively validated using a study by Faizal et al. [1] for different nano-fluids. According to the result of this reference, the higher density and lower specific heat of nanoparticles leads to a higher thermal efficiency and CuO nano-fluid causes the highest efficiency comparing with other three nano-fluids. Also, CuO and TiO2 nano-fluid show better performance than Al2O3. The results of this study, as presented in Figs. 13–15, are in good agreement with the result of Faizal et al. [1]. Since the performance of the solar collector is more efficient using CuO and TiO2 nano-fluids, it can be deduced that the overall exergy efficiency of the system should be higher than the reported values for Al2O3.
Exergy efficiency of the main components of the integrated system are presented in Table 5. The results are based on the solar irradiation of 746Wm 2 at 12 PM. It is observed that the exergy efficiency of all components are higher than 40% except the TES.

sections.heading: 6. Results and discussion
sections.text:
In this study, a solar Rankine cycle is analyzed in which parabolic trough solar collector system is used to provide the required energy for power generation. Four different nano-fluids based on CuO, SiO2, TiO2 and Al2O3 nano-powders are utilized as working fluid in trough collector system. A sensitivity analysis is performed to evaluate the performance of the solar Rankine cycle based on the variation of solar irradiation, environment temperature and nano-fluid void fraction.
The overall exergy efficiency of the system during charging and discharging mode are reported in Table 6 for different nano-fluids. The results are based on the assumption that for charging mode the input exergy is incident solar radiation exergy and for discharging mode the exergy stored in the TES system is considered as input exergy. It is concluded that the overall exergy efficiency during charging mode is higher comparing with discharging mode, since the inlet temperature to the evaporator is higher and it causes higher enthalpy of the outlet steam from the evaporator. Therefore, the net produced power and the overall exergy efficiency are enhanced.
It should be noted that the operating conditions of the Rankine cycle changes during charging and discharging mode. In fact, the flow rate is adjusted based on the input energy from the solar system.
As illustrated in Fig. 3, the inlet temperature of turbine decreases with increase of discharging time. After about 5.5 h, turbine inlet temperature is not enough high to provide the required energy for power generation. The effect of discharging time on the overall energy and exergy efficiencies of the system is shown in Fig. 4. Increase of the discharging time leads to lower energy and exergy efficiencies, due to lower inlet temperature of turbine and enthalpy of the outlet steam from the evaporator. Therefore, the net produced power and the overall exergy efficiency are decreased.

sections.heading: 6.1. Effect of solar irradiation
sections.text:
The effect of solar radiation intensity on the performance of the solar Rankine system is evaluated from exergy aspect of view. Fig. 5 shows the diurnal variation of solar radiation intensity and the overall energy and exergy efficiency without using
nano-fluid. The daily solar irradiation profile is based on available data for Delhi city on October 15th. It is concluded that by increase of solar irradiation energy and exergy efficiencies of the integrated system decrease. At 12 noon, when maximum solar radiation is available, minimum energy and exergy efficiencies are obtained. Increase of solar irradiation leads to higher heat transfer to the nano-fluid that results in increase of the output temperature of the solar collector and the inlet temperature of steam. Consequently, the generated power by turbine and the efficiency of Rankine cycle increase. However, based on Eqs. (32) and (48), the utilization of solar radiation is not as efficient as in the case of lower irradiations, and the overall energy and exergy efficiency of the cycle decrease.
The effects of solar radiation intensity on the overall energy and exergy efficiency for different nano-fluids are depicted in Figs. 6 and 7, respectively. It is found out that CuO nano-particle leads to higher energy and exergy efficiency as compared with other nano-fluids. By increase of solar irradiance from 450Wm 2 to 950Wm 2 the energy and exergy efficiency decrease from 0.19 to 0.12 and 0.41 to 0.31, respectively. As illustrated in Fig. 8, the outlet temperature of solar collector increases with increase of solar irradiation. Consequently, the net generated power is increased for different nano-fluids as demonstrated in Fig. 9. It is observed that the net power produced in case of using CuO nano-particles is relatively higher. This is due to lower specific heat
and higher density of CuO nano-particles in comparison with other nano-fluids (Table 1). Lower heat capacity and higher density of this nano-fluid result in more efficient energy absorption in the collector and higher temperature and enthalpy of the outlet steam from the evaporator. Therefore, the net produced power and the overall exergy efficiency are enhanced. This conclusion is verified based on the results of the study by Faizal et al. [1]. Also, the exergy and energy efficiencies are in good agreement with the reported values by Abid et al. [29].

sections.heading: 6.2. Effect of dead state temperature
sections.text:
The environment temperature that is regarded as dead state temperature for exergy analysis, affects the heat loss rate and also the exergy transfer associated with heat transfer. The effect of dead state temperature on the overall energy and exergy efficiencies of the solar Rankine cycle system is shown in Fig. 10. As demonstrated, at higher environment temperatures energy and exergy efficiencies are slightly increased due to lower heat loss from the solar receiver tube. In fact, the temperature difference between the surface of the receiver tube and working fluid decreases at higher dead state temperatures and it reduces the exergy losses. As a result, more power is produced and the overall exergy efficiency increases. With increase in dead state temperature from 280 K to 325 K the energy and exergy efficiencies are slightly increased from 0.126 to 0.128 and 0.174 to 0.178, respectively.

sections.heading: 6.3. Effect of nano-particle volume fraction
sections.text:
As shown in Fig. 13, the density of working fluid increases by increasing the volume fraction of nano-particles based on Eq. (3).
It is also observed that CuO based nano-fluid has the highest density comparing with other fluids. The effect of volume fraction of nano-particles on the specific heat of nano-fluid is also demonstrated in Fig. 14. Using Eq. (2) and based on information in Table 2, the specific heat of nano-fluid decreases by increasing the volume fraction of nanoparticles. Specific heat can be described as the amount of thermal energy that is required to raise the temperature of unit mass by one degree Celsius, therefore a nano-fluid with lower specific heat capacity requires less energy for one degree increase in temperature.
The effect of volume fraction of nano-particles on the overall energy and exergy efficiencies is illustrated in Figs. 15 and 16. As indicated in these results, by increase of nano-particles void fraction, the energy and exergy efficiencies slightly increase, and CuO causes the highest energy and exergy efficiency among the others. This is due to the fact that CuO/oil fluid has lower specific heat comparing with other nano-fluids, therefore the temperature raise of this nano-fluid due to solar irradiation is higher. Consequently, the evaporator outlet temperature, net power generation and the overall exergy efficiency are enhanced.

sections.heading: 6.4. Optimization results
sections.text:
The results of optimization for CuO nano-fluid at different times of a day are shown in Tables 7–9. Since the solar irradiation at 10 AM is less than irradiation at 12 PM, lower exergy efficiency and higher net output power can be achieved. This conclusion is also illustrated in Figs. 5, 7 and 9. It is revealed that almost 20% decrease in steam flow rate and two times higher nano-fluid volume fraction is required to reach the maximum exergy efficiency. Lower steam flow rate causes less exergy destruction in Rankine cycle and higher volume fraction enhances the solar energy absorption rate.
As previously shown in Fig. 5, radiation intensity is maximum at around 12 noon and the minimum exergy and energy efficiencies are achieved due to higher energy loss and exergy destruction in solar system. Therefore, optimization is performed for different nano-fluids at 12 PM as the worst case. The results of optimization of the system performance at 12 noon for different nano-fluids are shown in Tables 8 and 10–12. It is concluded that the optimum net output power when CuO, TiO2, Al2O3, and SiO2 nano-particles are utilized is 54.978 kW, 51.140 kW, 47.480 kW, and 43.024 kW,
respectively. Since the overall exergy efficiency increases with increasing the net output power of cycle, the optimum value of decision variables are introduced as input data to the simulation code to find the maximum possible exergy efficiency. The overall exergy efficiency in case of using CuO, TiO2, Al2O3, and SiO2 nano-particles can be increased from 0.311 to 0.321, 0.298 to 0.318, 0.264 to 0.294, and 0.243 to 0.266, respectively.

sections.heading: 7. Conclusions
sections.text:
In this study, the performance of an integrated Rankine power cycle with parabolic trough solar collector and a thermal energy storage system is evaluated using energy and exergy analysis method. Four different nano-fluids, namely CuO, SiO2, TiO2 and Al2O3, as working fluid in the solar trough collector system are examined. A mineral oil is utilized to store required energy for producing steam during 4 h when sufficient sunlight is not available. Parametric Analysis of the integrated cycle is performed based on the variation of dead state temperature, solar intensity and volume fraction of nano-fluids. The main conclusions from this study can be summarized as follows:
Increase of nano-particles void fraction causes slightly higher energy and exergy efficiencies of the integrated system. Increase of solar irradiation leads to higher nano-fluid heat transfer rate in the evaporator, higher power generation by the turbine and higher efficiency of the Rankine cycle, consequently.
The overall energy and exergy efficiencies when CuO/oil nanofluid is used are higher in comparison with other nano-fluids. The optimization results based on Genetic Algorithm at 12 noon show that the overall exergy efficiency of the system when CuO, TiO2, Al2O3, and SiO2 nano-particles are utilized can be increased by almost 3%, 6%, 11% and 9%, respectively. The results show that the overall exergy efficiency in case of using CuO, TiO2, Al2O3, and SiO2 nano-particles during charging mode are 0.321, 0.318, 0.294, and 0.243, respectively, that is considerably higher than discharging mode.

metadata.abstractText: In this paper, the performance of an integrated Rankine power cycle with parabolic trough solar system and a thermal storage system is simulated based on four different nano-fluids in the solar collector system, namely CuO, SiO2, TiO2 and Al2O3. The effects of solar intensity, dead state temperature, and volume fraction of different nano-particles on the performance of the integrated cycle are studied using second law of thermodynamics. Also, the genetic algorithm is applied to optimize the net output power of the solar Rankine cycle. The solar thermal energy is stored in a two-tank system to improve the overall performance of the system when sunlight is not available. The concept of Finite Time Thermodynamics is applied for analyzing the performance of the solar collector and thermal energy storage system. This study reveals that by increasing the volume fraction of nano-particles, the exergy efficiency of the system increases. At higher dead state temperatures, the overall exergy efficiency is increased, and higher solar irradiation leads to considerable increase of the output power of the system. It is shown that among the selected nano-fluids, CuO/oil has the best performance from exergy perspective. 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
